name: 5-(4-fluorophenyl)-3-[(4-methoxyphenyl)carbonyl]-3aH-pyrrolo[3,4-d]isoxazole-4,6(5H,6aH)-dione
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2295

name: 5-(4-fluorophenyl)-3-[(4-methoxyphenyl)carbonyl]-3aH-pyrrolo[3,4-d]isoxazole-4,6(5H,6aH)-dione
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2295
Reason:
The target compound consists of several functional groups, including a fluorophenyl group, an ester (carbonyl) connected to a methoxy-substituted phenyl group, and a pyrroloisoxazole dione system. To predict the melting point, we should consider the contributions from the following components and their consequent effects on the melting point relative to a simple molecule like benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C: 
- Benzene ring: This is our base unit. We start with the melting point of benzene (5.5). 
- Fluorophenyl group: Fluorine substitution generally increases melting point due to the inductive effect and increased molecular rigidity. Estimated effect: +40 °C.
- Methoxy-substituted phenyl group: Methoxy groups can increase the melting point due to the presence of the additional oxygen atom and the potential for intermolecular hydrogen bonding, but benzene rings have a stacking effect which may balance out the contributions. Estimated effect: +30 °C.
- Ester (carbonyl) group: Esters typically raise the melting point due to the possible dipole-dipole interactions and increased molecular weight. Estimated effect: +20 °C.
- Pyrroloisoxazole dione system: Heterocyclic and dione functionality will significantly increase the melting point because of the strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding and the rigidity of the system. Estimated effect: +45 °C.

Summing these contributions, we estimate an increase of +135 °C to the baseline melting point of benzene.
